text: March 1979 365 million miles from Earth
NASA's Voyager spacecraft hurtles toward
a massive mysterious world Jupiter is
the largest planet in our solar system
but it's not a planet like Earth that
you could walk on it's a gas giant that
gas is constantly in motion it's a very
turbulent atmosphere for you to deploys
its infrared sensors to collect
temperature data from the swirling mass
of Jupiter's clouds we expect to see
temperatures around 200 Kelvin which is
minus 100 degrees Fahrenheit it's pretty
cold but voyagers data reveals a
shocking anomaly the upper atmosphere of
Jupiter is much hotter than it should be
in fact what we find is it's 1,300
degrees Fahrenheit that's ridiculously
hot and hard to explain
what strange power source could be at
play on Jupiter in December 2016
scientists working with Hawaii's Mauna
Kea Observatory release new findings
that could offer a clue to the mystery
their temperature data comes from the
gas giants notorious red spot now
Jupiter's red spot is an extremely
intense very large storm as big as the
diameter of the earth could Jupiter's
giant red spots be blasting the
atmosphere with heat astronomer Tom
stalard is on the research team we saw a
spike in the radiation of light from the
upper atmosphere using our spectral
analysis we were able to show that that
was brighter because it was much hotter
and incredibly hot hundreds of degrees
hotter than the rest of the planet
scientists proposed the storms within
the red spot could be sending out sound
waves which transport energy through the
clouds when the waves hit the thin upper
atmosphere they release their energy as
heat
